content:
Hola, El tema que no es parte del protocolo de correo sincronizar etiquetas, algunos servidores de correo tipo Gmail u Outlook tienen categorías/etiquetas/marcas, las etiquetas de Gmail se representan como carpetas en el Thunderbird, la marca o "banderita roja" del Outlook se sincronizan como la estrella en Thunderbird, pero ninguno de estos servidores tienen las etiquetas de prioridades de Thunderbird por lo tanto como no lo tienen otro cliente de correo (otro Thunderbird) que sincronizan la misma cuenta de correo no puede sincronizar las etiquetas con el primer Thunderbird, esto mismo puede suceder con otros servidores de correo. Antiguamente había algunos complementos que servían para sincronizar las etiquetas de TB pero quedaron desactualizados y no funcionan con las versiones recientes.

Saludos

content: Maybe this is not relevant, but I am running (not by choice or happily) the Beta version of Thunderbird on my old computer. Not sure if this has an effect or is a cause of Thunderbird's inability to open the Profile copied per instructions to the new one. Any help would be appreciated.
creator: HonestJohn

content:
re :Maybe this is not relevant, but I am running (not by choice or happily) the Beta version of Thunderbird on my old computer.

If you are using the same version of beta on the new computer then it would not be a problem, but if you have installed the current release 102.7.0 on new machine then it could be a problem.

Profiles are now designed to be a dedicated profile per installation, which means it's not designed to be backwards compatible, but there is a workaround you could try. Info: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/dedicated-profile-thunderbird-installation

content:
The next obvious question, based around Thunderbird file access is what is blocking access to that file when Thunderbird tries to download mail that sees another created with the number appended.

Some of the more common things that can cause this occur are;

  • Antivirus scanning files "on access" Solution: place an exception in the anti virus to block such activity in the Thunderbird profile folders.
  • The location of the profile being somewhere unexpected like the documents folder, so Windows in particular treats the data somewhat differently. Solution: place the Thunderbird profile in a location that is at least not common with document files. Preferable the hidden application data folders that are default.
  • The location of the profile being synchronized to the cloud, via one drive, google drive etc. Solution: disable the cloud synchronization for that location.
  • The location of the profile is subject to streaming backups. Solution: cease the streaming backups on the profile folder as Thunderbird does not expect anything else to be accessing any of it's files.
  • The profile is not located on a local disk and either network latency or a slow server is seeing the files "served" in a less than timely manner. Solution: move the Thunderbird profile to a local disk.

I do not claim that to be an exhaustive list, but just some of the causes I have encountered on these support forums over the years, beyond the file being read only, either through the file system, or network policy or user access policy set on the machine. When checking in the file system to see if the file is "read only" check the security tab to see if you actually have write access to the file.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The profile is on my SSD "D" drive. I did just except the folder from on-demand virus scanning, so I will see how that goes.
